datasource: Hetzron, Robert. 1969. The Verbal System of Southern Agaw. Near Eastern Studies, vol. 12. Los Angeles: University of California Press.;  Hetzron, Robert. 1978. The nominal system of Awngi (Southern Agaw). Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies 41. 121–141; Zelealem Leyew & Yaregal Allene, 'Chapter 11: Awngi' in Ronny Meyer (ed.) et al. The Oxford Handbook of Ethiopian Languages, OUP, 2023, pp. 146-174.
datasourceNotes: Hetzron1969b, Chapter 2, ZZVerb ClassesZZ,  recognizes some 40 inflectional classes subdividing both the prefix and suffix-conjugation verbs. These are based on intersecting criteria of: ZZPatternZZ (base tone-pattern), ZZTypeZZ (associated png-marker set), and ZZGroupZZ (tone-effect on subsequent syllable). Pending a more thorough-going analysis, these classes are taken as brute inflectional classes, and are here designated according to the decimal subdivision of Chapter 2 where each class is identified.
geodemoTXT: Varieties and subdialects of Agaw (or Central) Cushitic language: Awngi is spoken mainly in the Amhara region, southwest of Lake Tana, and in scattered nearby localities. The variety represented here is that of the village of BertZZa Abbo in the province of Agawmeder, as described by Robert Hetzron in his 1969 monograph.
